I was just thinking, it's possible someone already mentioned this, 
but it might be useful to add a little noise to the *outputs* of the 
network.  In other words, if it asks to zoom, make it zoom a little 
more or a little less than it asked (i.e. add some noise).  If it 
asks to rotate, have a probability of slight over or under 
rotation.  Faustino Gomez from our group has shown that model noise 
(noise added to actions) is more effective than noise added to 
sensors.  Anyway, the point here would be that it would have to 
learn to deal with rotations it hasn't seen before.  The danger of 
course is that too much noise will make evaluation meaningless, so 
you'd have to be careful.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@y...> wrote:
> At 18:31 08/11/2004, you wrote:
> 
> >On Mon, 08 Nov 2004 16:56:18 +0000, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@y...> 
wrote:
> > >          I read your paper.
> > >
> > >          It's good.  The only comment I had is the same one I 
had before,
> > > that you do not define the "nearest neighbour" algorithm used 
in zooming
> > > the images and the picture you show does not look like what I 
think of as
> > > nearest neighbour.  But I doubt that many in your audience 
will pick up on
> > > that and I don't know whether it matters anyway...
> >
> >Thanks for the feedback, Ian.
> >
> >Yes, we could have spent a bit more space discussing interpolation
> >algorithms, but thought it might be a distraction.  We might 
possibly
> >be asked to add something in by reviewers, if it makes it that 
far.
> >
> > >          In what sense is the image processing the 
bottleneck?  Is is
> > > because you have to zoom, translate and rotate the viewed 
portion of the
> > > image in every evaluation frame?
> >
> >Yes, basically.  Each individual gets about 100 steps to move 
across
> >the canvass and view portions of the image.  On a given step, the
> >image can be moved up/down, left/right, zoomed in/out, and 
rotated, so
> >there's an affine transform for every step, and this is
> >computationally expensive.
> >
> > >  Writing your own (simple) image manipulation in
> > > C will cut the run-time hugely.  If you are already doing that 
then your
> > > problem is more severe...
> >
> >No, right now we're using Java's image processing package.  We're
> >looking at using a package called ImageMagick, and exploiting 
native
> >methods to speed up the processing.
> >
> >But we also hope to use Jim's SEMIANN neural net framework to gain
> >some speed there.
> 
> Hi,
>          Just one small thought on this.  That since what you want 
is a 
> fairly simple zoom/rotate facility, it may be than these packages 
are over 
> the top for your needs.  In which case some simple hand coding 
might out 
> perform them...
> 
>                  Ian
> 
> 
> Living@Home - Open Source Evolving Organisms -
